questions.question:
Question 1: Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses  
 as its second messenger.
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin acts on the V2 receptor using cAMP as its second messenger. Vasopressin acts on GPCR using different second messengers to accomplish its various actions as 
follows: • V1 receptor - vasoconstriction using phospholipase C as its second messenger • V2 receptor - reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, using cAMP as its second messenger 53 
Sold by @itachibot Vasopressin has a maximum effect on the collecting ducts. It acts by inserting aquaporin 
2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following act as the second messenger for secretin?
questions.explanation:
cAMP is the second messenger for the hormone secretin. It regulates fluid and electrolyte 
secretion and also mediates water and nutrient reabsorption.

questions.question: Question 3: Which hormone mediates its action via cyclic GMP?
questions.explanation:
Nitric oxide mediates its action via cyclic GMP or cGMP. cGMP is the second messenger associated with smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Atrial 
natriuretic factor (ANF) and NO (nitric oxide) are the only hormones that mediate their action via 
cGMP. Note: Recent studies show that NO is a hormone. NO, which functions as a chemical messenger, 
has similar properties to hormones (which are known as the body's chemical messengers).

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most abundant hormone produced by the pituitary gland?
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone (GH) is the most abundant hormone produced by the pituitary gland. It is produced by the acidophil cells or somatotropes of the anterior pituitary, which account for 
50% of the anterior pituitary cell population. Option A: Vasopressin is produced in the hypothalamus and only stored in the posterior pituitary. Option C: Corticotrophs account for 10% of the anterior pituitary cell population. Option D: Thyrotrophs account for 5% of the anterior pituitary cell population.

questions.question: Question 5: Insulin acts on which of the following?
questions.explanation: Insulin acts on the tyrosine kinase receptor, a cell-surface receptor.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is considered the twin hormone of prolactin?
questions.explanation:
GH and prolactin are called twin hormones as both are secreted by the acidophil cells of the 
anterior pituitary. They act on cytokine receptors and show JAK-STAT activity. 54 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following hormones is an amino acid derivative?
questions.explanation: The thyroid hormone is synthesized from tyrosine residues and thus is an amino acid derivative. Insulin, activin and parathyroid hormone are large protein hormones.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following chemical molecules is not a steroid hormones?
questions.explanation:
Inhibin is a large protein hormone, not a steroid hormone. All adrenocortical and reproductive hormones are steroid hormones synthesized from cholesterol 
precursors except activin and inhibin.

questions.question: Question 9: Which class of hormones does insulin belong to?
questions.explanation:
Insulin is classified as a large protein hormone (>50 amino acid residues) as it is composed of 
51 amino acids. Protein and polypeptide hormones are classified as small peptides (< 50 amino acid residues) 
and large proteins.

questions.question: Question 10: The action of cAMP is mediated by
questions.explanation:
The action of cAMP is mediated by protein kinases. cAMP is a second messenger molecule associated with electrolyte secretion and water and 
nutrient reabsorption. It is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase but it mediates its actions via protein 
kinases.

questions.question: Question 11: The second messenger, cAMP is synthesized by the enzyme
questions.explanation: cAMP is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase, but it mediates its actions via protein kinases.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not activated by the binding of epinephrine to its receptor?
questions.explanation:
The binding of epinephrine to its various receptors results in the activation of different types 
of G-protein subunits, namely Gq, Gi, and Gs. All catecholamines act via G protein-coupled receptors. This stimulates cAMP production 
and signaling via protein kinases. 55 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: The enzyme kinase adds  
 to proteins.
questions.explanation:
Kinases are a subclass of transferases that catalyze the transfer of a phosphate group from a donor 
to an acceptor protein. They are associated with the regulation of many essential cellular 
processes. 56 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Anterior Pituitary
